Award.AwardTitle: Atkinson's Fungi: Curation and databasing at the Cornell Plant Pathology Herbarium
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite their importance as recyclers, symbionts, and pathogens, fungi are among the least known terrestrial organisms. This project focuses on the mushrooms and other fungi collected by George F. Atkinson, now stored in the Cornell Plant Pathology Herbarium. Atkinson described over 300 new fungi from the Northeastern US in the late 1800s and early 1900s, while amassing a collection of about 109,000 preserved specimens. The project will result in digital access to specimen information, linked with Atkinson?s own notes and images of living fungi, and will stabilize the specimens themselves for long-term preservation. An important impact of the project will be to improve understanding of the diversity and distribution of fungi, a critical group in that about 95% of fungal species have not yet been described by science.


The project will introduce many undergraduate students and citizens to the value and uses of biological collections, including them in all aspects of collection management. It will promote public appreciation of fungi and their ecological impacts through identification workshops, forays, and exhibits. Project outreach will also be provided through the collection's website, and through a series of articles about Atkinson and his fungi on the Cornell Mushroom Blog.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fungi are key members of all of earth's ecosystems: they support agricultural and forest habitats, and are key players in carbon cycling as agents of disease and decay. Many are useful to us in medicines (e. g., penicillin), foods and beverages (e. g. yeasts), and industrial products (e. g. citric acid), yet the majority of fungi are not well known. Over 90% of fungi do not even have names yet. The field of fungal biology aims to come to know the great diversity and impacts of molds, yeasts, and mushrooms on our planet. Preserved collections of fungi (herbaria) are current and historical repositories of fungal diversity, yet in many collections, information about fungi found before the digital age is locked up and difficult to access. This project aimed to unlock historical information about the thousands of fungi that were collected and studied by George F. Atkinson, an influential biologist of the early 1900s.

Atkinson's fungus specimens are stored in the Cornell Plant Pathology Herbarium, but access to them was limited and the collection had never been indexed. This project captured information about these fungi, and made it available on the internet. The information can be used in traditional ways—to support our understanding of the diversity of fungi—but also in novel ones, such as to investigate the ecology of mushrooms, gauge the impacts of climate change on fruiting patterns of fungi, or to help predict patterns of disease in agricultural crops. The captured information includes data on over 45,000 preserved specimens collected by Atkinson, building a snapshot of fungal biodiversity in the early 1900s. We scanned his 8000 early scientific photographs of these mushrooms—he photographed freshly collected specimens, so the images give important information about what a fungus looked like before it was dried and preserved. Atkinson died before completing a planned major book on American mushrooms; we scanned his 4600 pages of notes that provide insight on his scientific hypotheses about mushroom species. We discovered and cataloged over 1000 Type Specimens of fungi in Atkinson's collection. These Types are important each is the first of its kind to be described and named; each Type provides a solid physical foundation that defines its individual species.

The main intellectual impact of our project was to unlock a large store of data about a poorly known group of organisms. No complete list of all fungi known from either the US or the world has yet been created. Together with data from peer institutions, our information will help build the first list of American fungi, via the publicly available community resource, MyCoPortal, to which we are all contributing.

The project has broader impact at several levels. A key outcome is the continued development of scientific capacity in fungal biology, a field of great human impacts that is under-explored: our project trained 33 students in collections-based research. Students participated fully in handling specimens, digitizing their data, scanning 8000 photographs, preserving Atkinson's glass photographic negatives, and resolving conflicts around the correct names of the fungi in the Atkinson collection. The students learned about fungi and their roles in ecosystems, as well as the ways of storing and using them for research. Several students participated in our public outreach efforts, including hosting an annual New York State mushroom foray in Atkinson's honor, offering tours of the herbarium, and writing articles related to the project that are now available online. Our group mounted a major public exhibition, 'Focus on Fungus,' at Cornell University's biology library in 2013.
